Sector Regulation

9. 
The regulatory framework in the telecoms sector shows the typical nondivision of policy
making  and  regulation  functions.  The  regulatory  function  rests  with  the  Director  General  of
Post  and  Telecommunications  Department  under  MCST,  who  is  also  responsible  for  policy
development and strategic planning of the telecoms sector. This vague demarcation of the two
functions is made more complicated by another responsibility resting with the Director General
    that  of  a  board  member  of  Dhiraagu,  the  monopoly  service  provider.  Consequently,
virtually  all  three  functions  (cid:190)
  are  mixed  and
involve the Director General. The board of Dhiraagu consists of seven members, four of whom
are government officials (cid:190)
 the Minister of Foreign Affairs, the Minister of Trade and Industries,
the Managing Director of the Transport and Contracting Company, and the Director General.
The  Minister  of  Foreign  Affairs  holds  the  chairmanship  of  the  board.  Under  this  framework,
independent  regulatory  decisions  by  the  Director  General  cannot  be  expected.  Moreover,
since  the  Director  General,  as  a  board  member  of  Dhiraagu,  serves  the  benefits  of  the
operator  under  the  chairmanship  of  a  senior  government  official,  the  regulatory  role  tends  to
be  overshadowed  by  other  conflicting  agenda,  and  consequently  becomes  weakened.  This
structure might have been justified at its inception by the need to maintain the profitability of
Dhiraagu,  and  at  the  same  time  to  extend  service  into  new  locations  and  build  infrastructure
for  new  telecoms  technologies;  however,  with  this  conflicting  interrelationship  between  the
regulator and the operator, the regulator cannot cause Dhiraagu to lower rates, which currently
promote an excess return on capital, thus resulting in disservice to customers.

10. 
Effective  telecoms  access  consists  of  both  physical  access  to  the  system  and  the
ability to afford to use the system in an efficient manner. Currently, the telephone and Internet
physical access provided by Dhiraagu partly satisfies the first condition for telephone services,
but less so for Internet access, which is often connected at below-capacity speeds and is often
undependable outside Male. The costs of telephone service, especially international calls and
Internet access are almost prohibitive for economic use.

11. 
The affordability of telecoms services can be improved by promoting competition in the
market  and  introducing  an  appropriate  regulatory  regime.  Government  policy  foresees  the
introduction of new Internet service providers into the Internet market as a means of improving
the  affordability  of  these  services.  Cellular  mobile  service  and  long  distance  calling  are  both
potentially profitable activities for private providers and could draw private sector interest. The
present  system  of  intranational  telephone  services,  however,  exists  as  a  natural  monopoly,
and  it  is  unlikely  that  any  private  competitor  would  find  it  profitable  to  enter  the  market.  An
independent  and  transparent  regulatory  regime,  therefore,  emerges  as  an  important  issue  to
ensure the affordability of telecoms services.

B. 

Government Sector Objectives and Plans

1.

Telecommunications Sector

15. 
Taking  into  account  these  conditions  and  the  national  development  priorities  of  the
Maldives, the Government has decided to move toward a more open competitive environment
in the telecoms system. This move is reinforced by the international trend in telecoms markets
to contestability and competition, and the World Trade Organization protocol on liberalization
of markets for telecoms.

16. 
In  this  context,  the  Government,  based  on  the  recommendations  of  the  Science  and
Technology Master Plan, intends to make the policy decisions to (i) establish a new regulatory
regime to allow for effective management of monopoly and dominant behaviors to the extent
necessary to facilitate an efficient transition to a contestable market for telecoms services; (ii)
enact  new  legislation  that  will  regulate  the  telecoms  industry  in  an  independent  and
transparent  manner,  encourage  competition,  and  inhibit  anticompetitive  practices;  and  (iii)
liberalize the market for Internet services and possibly selected other services not covered by
current exclusivity arrangements between the Government and Dhiraagu.

17. 
To  support  implementation  of  the  policy,  the  Government  will  devise  action  plans
encompassing  (i)  reducing  the  charges  for  telecoms  services,  especially  for  Internet  and
international  call  services,  including  narrowing  the  difference  in  charges  between  Male  and
uninhabited islands; (ii) providing universal service, including expanding mobile services to the
whole  country;  (iii)  developing  an  independent  regulatory  body  equipped  with  financial
autonomy;  (iv)  opening  up  markets  to  competition  for  those  services  for  which  Dhiraagu  has
no exclusivity rights; (v) minimizing any adverse impact of tariff restructuring on fiscal revenue
by  pursuing  expansion  of  the  revenue  base;  (vi)  improving  telecoms  facilities  and  upgrading
telecoms services as a way of attracting foreign investors, including obtaining access to global
submarine cables; and (vii) ultimately transforming the Maldives into an ICT society.

2.

Public Sector Management

18. 
Good  governance  is  one  of  the  key  development  objectives  highlighted  by  the  Sixth
National Development Plan (2001-2005). The establishment of a modern public administration
is emphasized as a priority goal in the Government’s development agenda. Capacity building
and  the  upgrading  of  human  resources  to  fill  skills  gaps  have  been  recognized  as  critical
requirements  toward  good  governance  to  achieve  improved  performance  of  public  sector
management.  The  Sixth  Plan  also  emphasizes  regional  development  through  promoting
equitable  access  to  social  services  and  economic  infrastructure,  which  is  one  of  the  major
thrusts  pursued  by  the  Project  through  establishing  a  government  network  and  providing  the
public with better access to it.

As  a  way  of  improving  the  efficiency  and  transparency  of  public  sector  management,
19. 
the  Government  plans  to  develop  a  common  data  communication  network  between  the
ministries and other parastatal agencies. The government network will be a facility designed to
support communications through virtual networks within ministries, to support the exchange of
information  between  ministries,  and  to  provide  a  secure  gateway  between  the  Government
and the Internet. The network will comprise two separate components: a metropolitan network
serving ministry offices located within Male, and a wide area regional network extending from
Male to serve the atoll capitals and eventually island administration offices.

C. 

External Assistance to the Sector

20. 
ADB provided TA for the Science and Technology Master Plan (footnote 1) in 2000. As
part of that TA, a master plan for telecoms and ICT sector development in the Maldives was
prepared.  In  1999,  UNDP  sponsored  the  GNM  Study,  which  triggered  ADB’s  involvement  in
the  sector.  With  the  increasing  importance  of  ICT  for  economic  growth  and  governance
improvement,  however,  many  aid  agencies  look  to  the  benefits  of  rationalization  of  the
telecoms,  and  ICT  sector  in  Maldives.  The  International  Telecommunications  Union  assisted
with  preparation  of  the  telecoms  sector  policy,  which  provided  a  basis  for  the  Maldives
Telecommunication  Policy  approved  by  the  Government  on  1  August  2001.  UNDP  is
considering  a  support  program  to  conduct  a  study  for  promoting  competition  in  the  Internet
service market.

D.

1.

Telecommunications Sector Policy

28. 
Since  the  incumbent  service  provider  is  already  incorporated  with  a  minority  share
owned by a foreign strategic partner with exclusivity in fixed voice services, the policy dialogue
between ADB and the Government has been focused on (i) establishment of an independent
regulatory  body,  (ii)  liberalization  of  value-added  and  other  nonbasic  services,  and  (iii)
enactment  of  a  telecoms  law  that  supports  the  transparent  regulatory  framework  and  the
liberalization of telecoms markets. On 1 August 2001, the Government approved the Maldives
Telecommunication Policy 2001-2005 (the Telecoms Policy), which addresses all sector policy
issues  discussed  and  sets  a  time  frame  for  critical  sector  reform  measures.  The  Telecoms
Policy  identifies  six  sector  policy  goals:  (i)  reducing  charges  for  all  telecoms  services;  (ii)
expanding  telecoms  services  and  narrowing  the  differences  in  cost  of  service  provision
between  Male  and  the  other  islands;  (iii)  providing  necessary  means  and  legal  powers  to
strengthen the role of the regulator through an appropriate legislative framework; (iv) opening
the  Maldives  telecoms  market  for  competition;  (v)  making  government  revenues  from  the
telecoms  sector  less  dependent  on  the  profit  of  the  sector;  and  (vi)  making  the  Maldives  an
extensive user of ICT in all aspects of development, thereby setting a replicable example for
the South Asia region.

2.

Tariff Restructuring and Rebalancing

29. 
The  large  gap  in  telephone  installation  and  monthly  charges  between  Male  and  the
other  islands  will  be  reduced  to  achieve  universal  service  provision.  The  gap  between
international and local call charges will be narrowed by reducing the international call charges
to destinations where there is significant traffic from the Maldives, reducing accounting rates,
introducing  additional  international  telephone  services,  and  allowing  wider  use  of  Internet
phone service. Internet dial-up service will be provided on a virtually free basis by separating
Internet  charges  from  telephone  usage  charges  and  introducing  flat  rate  usage  packages
instead of charging per minute.

30. 
Apart  from  these  specific  tariff  restructuring  efforts,  regulatory  efforts  will  also  be
exercised  to  set  tariffs  based  on  the  cost  of  services.  Service  providers  will  be  required  to
maintain separate accounting for different services. Separating mobile service providers from
fixed service providers and disallowing a service provider to provide both services under one
roof  will  be  considered  to  ensure  clear-cut  separation  of  accounting  and  to  avoid  cross-
subsidization between the two services.

IV.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A. 

Rationale

33. 
The  population  of  the  Maldives  was  around  280,000  in  2000,  spread  among  200
inhabited  islands.  About  67,000  people  or  24  percent  of  the  population  live  on  the  capital
island  of  Male.  There  is  an  inward  migration  trend  from  the  atolls  to  Male  as  people  seek
employment  and  better  education.  Those  living  outside  Male  depend  on  fishing,  agriculture,
and  other  primary  industry-related  activities  for  their  livelihood.  Many  families  depend  on
money  transfers  from  family  members  employed  in  Male  or  on  tourist  resorts.  The
decentralization  of  economic  activities  away  from  Male  is  hampered  by  the  lack  of  basic
infrastructure  and  the  poorly  developed  interisland  transportation  system.  With  these
geographical  and  economical  characteristics,  the  Maldives  has  a  huge  potential  to  take  full
advantage of ICT, as it allows distribution of, and access to, information at no cost difference
regardless  of  different  spatial  distances.  A  majority  of  people  living  in  the  atolls  could  be
empowered  by  ICT  to  gain  access  to  public  services  at  as  affordable  a  price  as  enjoyed  by
people  in  Male.  Even  people  in  Male  could  save  time  and  effort,  again  thanks  to  ICT,  by
having  access  to  public  services  on-line  rather  than  over  the  counter.  Recognizing  this
potential of ICT, the Government has put forward ICT as its prime tool to promote sustainable
economic growth.

ICT  has  significantly  changed  the  conventional  concept  of  interaction  between
34. 
businesses  and  between  businesses  and  customers.  Commerce  based  on  ICT  has  almost
revolutionized  the  way  of  doing  business,  making  transactions  between  businesses  far  more
efficient,  and  bringing  customers  much  closer  to  the  businesses.  ICT  has  also  caused  a
revolutionary  change  in  doing  government  work,  which  has  brought  about  more  efficiency,
more  transparency,  and  more  accountability.  Enormous  efficiency  gains  can  result  from
networking  government  agencies,  which  will  allow  them  to  share  and  exchange  information
on-line.  Disclosure  of  government  information  through  the  Web  will  make  government  more
open and accountable. Delivery of government services through the Web will decrease face-
to-face  contact  with  government  employees,  which  will  lead  to  less  corruption,  and  hence  to
enhanced governance. Particularly in the Maldives, a small island country, where the majority
of its people are scattered throughout hundreds of islands, the benefits of e-government will be
far more extensive, especially compared with its networking cost.

35. 
The  benefits  expected  from  networking  government  may  not  accrue  to  the  public
unless  the  public  is  allowed  to  get  access  to  the  government  network  at  an  affordable  price.
High tariffs for Internet service in many developing countries are attributed to policy failure that
results in lack of competition in the telecoms market and lack of appropriate regulation. It has
been  shown  that  countries  with  a  highly  liberalized  telecoms  network  have  costs  of  Internet
access several times lower than those with a completely closed market. Countries with more

 9

open  telecoms  sectors  also  have  more  host  sites,  lower  monthly  Internet  charges,  a  greater
number of service providers, and higher rates of Internet penetration. In the Maldives, the high
tariffs of Internet and data transmission services are regarded as a major stumbling block for
the  expansion  of  Internet  penetration.  With  the  current  tariff  structure,  the  efforts  of  the
Government to bring the public closer to government information and public services through
government  networking  will  prove  fruitless.  Telecoms  sector  reform  will,  therefore,  be  an
indispensable direction that should come along with the Government’s efforts to promote ICT.

The Project is needed to encourage the Government to take advantage of ICT for its
36.

delivering  better  public  services  to  the  public,  aided  by  the  telecoms  sector  reform  that  will
accompany the Project.

A. 

Project Benefits and Beneficiaries

87. 
The  benefits  of  the  establishment  of  a  government  network  are  wide  ranging  and
include  improved  efficiency,  transparency,  and  accountability  of  government  activities;
accelerated decentralization of government work; and positive impacts on the poorer section
of the population. Greater efficiency in government management will be achieved through the
government  intranet,  the  applications  supported  under  the  Project,  and  those  that  will  be
developed  by  the  various  departments.  Greater  transparency  and  accountability  will  result
from  the  wider  availability  of  more  reliable  information  on  regulations,  requirements,  and
programs. The Government’s decentralization policies will be facilitated through the linking of
the  atoll  offices  into  the  government  wide-area  network.    Finally,  by  providing  free  access  to
government  websites  in  the  atoll  offices  and  in  Male,  the  Project  will  benefit  those  for  whom
the cost of access to government services would otherwise remain prohibitively high.

88. 
The  cost  of  government  activities  can  be  reduced  through  (i)  reduced  cost  of  data
collection,  (ii)  faster  processing  and  availability  of  information,  (iii)  wider  availability  of
information and data in a uniform format across all branches of government, (iv) reductions in
travel  and  paper  transmission  between  offices  and  islands,  and  (v)  more  effective
communication  between  the  various  branches  of  government.  Some  benefits  will  be  direct
while  others  will  be  indirect  in  nature.  The  beneficiaries  of  these  improvements  will  be  all
citizens who will benefit from more efficient management of the nation’s resources.

89. 
The  benefits  of  the  sector  reform  component  include  (i)  a  substantial  lowering  of
telecom rates in line with international levels, (ii) increased internal efficiency in the services of
the telecom operator(s), (iii) availability of a greater range of services, and (iv) better quality of
services.  Some  of  these  benefits  are  direct  in  nature  and  are  more  easily  quantifiable,  while
other  benefits  are  of  an  indirect  nature.  The  lowering  of  rates  combined  with  the  qualitative
benefits  will  significantly  reduce  the  private  cost  of  domestic  and  international  business  and
commerce  and  hence  provide  a  boost  to  economic  growth.  The  beneficiaries  of  the  sector
reform  will  be  mainly  comprised  of  existing  users.  However,  the  lowering  of  rates  will  make
telecoms more affordable to large sections of the population and the business community and
will generate additional demand for telecoms services, in turn giving rise to economic benefits
from increased economic activity.

Economic Analysis

90. 
The  economic  analysis  was  carried  out  separately  for  each  of  the  components  and
sub-components,  comparing  the  “with-Project”  and  “without-Project”  situations  based  on  an
economic  life  of  the  investment  of  15  years  with  no  residual  value.  Demand  for  the  various
applications  was  developed  using  the  findings  of  an  Internet  access  and  usage  survey.
Investment and annual operating costs are expressed in economic terms (excluding all taxes)
using  mid-2001  prices  and  include  a  physical  contingency  where  appropriate.  A  standard
conversion  factor  of  0.9  was  applied  to  nontraded  items  and  labor. The  overall  economic
internal rate of return (EIRR) of the Project is 25 percent. When all the negative scenarios, as
analyzed  for  each  component,  are  combined,  the  EIRR  is  calculated  as  15  percent  for  the
overall Project. Details on cost and benefit estimates and calculations are shown in Appendix
10.

1. 

Government Network

91. 
The  benefits  of  this  component  consist  mainly  of  greater  productivity  of  government
personnel  through  reduced  cost  of  data  collection,  faster  processing,  and  more  timely  and
wider  availability  of  information;  reductions  in  travel  and  paper  transmission;  and  more
effective communication between branches of government. All citizens of the nation will benefit
from more efficient government. The improved productivity, which will translate into savings in
government  employment,  is  the  basis  for  the  economic  analysis.  Indirect  benefits,  although
significant, have not been quantified.

92. 
The  critical  factor  for  the  analysis  is  the  scale  and  pace  at  which  networking  will  be
adopted  within  government.  Initial  usage  of  the  networking  and  growth  in  usage  have  been
estimated  taking  into  account  the  Government’s  policies  and  measures  to  make  an  effective
transition to a predominantly paperless mode of operation.  Past employment trends and the
Government’s  current  personnel  policies  aimed  at  redesigning  government  functions  and  job
descriptions and containing the growth of staff form the frame of reference for projecting total
government  employment  with  and  without  the  Project.  The  Project  would  lead  to  savings  in
personnel of 309 staff five years after the start of the Project, growing to more than 2,960 after
15 years. The EIRR of the investment is 19 percent. This outcome is sensitive to the rate at
which the Government will be able to stabilize employment levels through attrition. However, if
the savings in government personnel are 25 percent less than assumed in the base case, the
EIRR would still be 15 percent with a switching value of 0.85.

2. 

National Citizens Identification Application

93. 
This  application  will  bring  greater  efficiency  in  government  activities  by  avoiding
duplication in the creation and updating of personal data records by the various agencies and
departments that interact with the population at large. Again all the citizens of the nation will
benefit from the efficiencies obtained from this application. The economic evaluation is based
on  the  time  savings  of  government  departments  from  accessing  and  using  the  personal
identification (ID) record from the national ID register rather than creating and updating such
records themselves. The critical factors for the economic analysis are the potential maximum
use  that  can  be  made  of  the  application,  i.e.,  the  number  of  times  the  ID  record  will  be
accessed,  and  the  initial  use  and  rate  at  which  the  level  of  use  will  grow  towards  their  full
potential.  The  number  of  times  the  ID  record  will  be  accessed  once  fully  implemented is
estimated at a total of 1.4 million annually. During the first year only 50 percent of this potential
will  be  realized,  growing  to  100  percent  in  the  fourth  year.  The  average  time  saving  is
estimated at 15 minutes, and the hourly time cost for government employees is Rf21. On this
basis the EIRR is 42 percent. If it takes six years to achieve the full potential and if the time

saving is only 10 minutes on average, the EIRR will still be 21 percent with a switching value
of 0.85.

3. 

Hospital Information System

94. 
The main direct benefit of the introduction of ICT at the hospital is higher productivity
through,  among  others,  single  patient  registration,  instant  availability  of  medical  records,
reductions  in  all  kinds  of  processing,  and  real  time  availability  of  medical  and  accounting
information. Indirect benefits include enhanced quality of health care. The beneficiaries are the
citizens of the nation and the patients. The economic evaluation is based on the time savings
of doctors and other staff made possible with the introduction of ICT. These time savings are
estimated  from  achievable  productivity  levels  as  derived  from  efficient  hospitals  in  a
comparable country setting. It is estimated that productivity can be increased by 25 percent for
doctors  and  by  90  percent  for  other  staff.  The  key  factor  for  the  economic  analysis  is  the
efficiency level that can be achieved in the initial years and the number of years it will take to
achieve the full efficiency potential. It is estimated that, during the first year after introduction of
ICT,  efficiency  will  only  be  25  percent  of  the  full  potential,  and  that  the  full  potential  will be
achieved after a four-year period. Productivity increases will be absorbed by the growth in the
volume  of  activity,  which  is  estimated  at  10  percent  per  annum  based  on  past  trends.  When
the  full  potential  of  the  savings  has  been  reached,  these  will  amount  to  Rf21.7  million  per
annum.  Assuming  that  half  of  these  savings  can  be  attributed  to  the  introduction  of  ICT,  the
EIRR  is  35  percent.  If  it  is  assumed  that  it  will  take  six  years  for  the  full  potential  to  be
achieved, the EIRR is 29 percent with a switching value of 0.43.

C.

Poverty Reduction Impact

98. 
The Project primarily aims at improving the efficiency, transparency, and accountability
of  public  sector  management  and  setting  up  a  regulatory  regime  that  will  encourage  fair
competition in the telecoms sector. This will percolate to the outer island level and broadly help
to reduce poverty in two ways. First, the provision of information and services via the Internet
system  will  lead  to  wider  social  inclusion  of  the  poor  by  enabling  direct  access  to  public
information. In this way, rather than relying on the bureaucracy, the poor will be able to access
such  information  directly  through  the  Internet.  In  particular,  the  provision  of  information  and
services in the areas of health and education will change the basic life pattern of people in the
islands. The provision of health information and services will considerably reduce waiting time.
It  will  enable  them  to  make  crucial  choices  in  terms  of  traveling  and  leaving  their  families
behind.  This  will  translate  into  savings  and  the  ability  to  make  alternative  expenditure
decisions,  which  may  otherwise  not  be  possible.  Over  the  long  run,  as  the  Internet  services
expand from single kiosks to widespread use in schools and other learning centers, it will open
up a new world of information that will greatly facilitate distance education and other modes of
informal learning in a diverse number of areas including vocational education and specialized
training and skills development.

99. 
Second,  access  to  social  services  and  public  information  will  lead  to  greater
empowerment of the poor. Their life circumstances will acquire a greater degree of certainty,
which presently eludes them. The ability to utilize the service for such things as reporting fish
catch,  obtaining  information  on  fish  prices  and  trends  in  the  demand  for  local  products  (fish
and  agricultural  products),  and  applying  for  licenses  will  benefit  poor  communities  through
savings in time and resources and better organization of their activities. This will increase their
general independence and self-reliance.

100.  This  will in  turn create the conditions for enhancing their economic life and launching
new  income-generating  activities  by  reducing  the  costs  of  establishing  businesses  through

 22

lower transportation costs and eliminating the need to travel to Male to obtain information and
services.

101.  At the moment there is an imbalance in the availability of telecommunication services.
However, the wider availability of such services under the Project, especially to areas that are
presently  underserved,  will  help  to  reduce  regional  differences  and  close  the  gap  between
spatially  disadvantaged  groups.  It  will  provide  an  opportunity  to  address  the  disadvantages
that  arise  from  geographical  location  and  to  improve  communications  and  employment
opportunities.  This  will,  by  the  same  token,  help  to  generate  greater  economies  of  scale
through  reduction  in  the  cost  of  services,  which  is  presently  the  single-most  important
constraint in reducing poverty in small island communities.

102.  Overall,  the  opportunities  for  economic  progress  will  be  enhanced  over  the  long  term
through greater efficiency resulting from lower costs and timely access to services.

D.

Private Sector Development

103.  The  Project  will  contribute  to  the  creation  of  enabling  conditions  for  private  sector
operations,  specifically  by  improving  governance,  in  line  with  ADB’s  Private  Sector
Development  Strategy.  The  Project  will  make  public  administration  more  transparent,  cause
sector regulations to be sound, check corruption in the public sector, reduce transaction costs
for  public  sector  management,  and  establish  efficient  and  competitive  telecoms  service
markets,  all of which  will  eventually help promote private sector participation in the telecoms
sector. The sector reforms pursued by the Project, especially opening up of telecoms service
markets,  will  accelerate  divestment  of  the  Government’s  share  in  the  monopoly  service
provider in the Maldives. Lower communication costs enabled by the sector reforms, and lower
transaction  costs  with  the  Government  resulting  from  public  services  provided  electronically
will  promote  private  sector  economic  and  business  activities.  The  Project  will  also  promote
direct involvement of the private sector in the course of its implementation. The establishment
of  the  government  network  and  applications  for  e-government  will  be  bid  out  on  a  turnkey
basis to the private sector. O&M of the government network and portals could be contracted
out  to  the  private  sector.  O&M  of  Internet  kiosks  will  also  be  contracted  out  to  the  private
sector or to village communities.

E.

Project Risks

104.  Relating to O&M of project equipment, including the network, applications, and Internet
kiosks, two risks need to be addressed. The first is the financial sustainability of O&M. Since
no financial revenue is expected from the operation of project equipment, O&M will depend on
government  budgetary  resources  of  project  equipment.  The  Project  will  ensure  the
Government’s commitment to allocate appropriate budgetary resources through the conditions
of  the  Loan.  The  second  risk  concerns  who  will  operate  and  maintain  the  network  and
applications.  NCC  will  act  as  the  focal  point  for  O&M.  The  Project  will  provide  an  extensive
training  program  for  NCC  staff  as  part  of  the  network  and  applications  development
components.

105.  The  most  significant  potential  risk  is  how  to  motivate  government  agencies  to
proactively participate in the Project, and to cooperate with each other to establish the network
and share their information across all agencies. This risk will be addressed by launching large-
scale  awareness  campaigns  at  the  initial  stage  of  the  Project.  The  consulting  services  for
detailed  design  of  the  network  and  applications  will  include  devising  and  executing  such
awareness campaigns for government agencies.

 23

106.  Since  the  realization  of  the  benefits  is  hinged  on  affordable  Internet  tariffs  for  the
public, the success of the Project is subject to the success of the telecoms sector reform that
will be implemented as part of it. The plan for the reform, agreed upon with the Government,
will  commit  the  Government  to  undertake  the  reform  under  an  agreed  upon  timetable.  To
ensure the success of the reform, a holistic approach will be taken by integrating sector and
cross-sector  efforts  and  thereby  maximizing  the  leverage  effect  of  ADB’s  assistance.  In  the
course,  an  effort  will  be  made  to  involve  the  highest  authority  as  a  strong  supporter  for  the
reform.  Successful  implementation  of  the  sector  reform  is  closely  linked  to  the  regulatory
capacity of the independent regulatory body that will be established as part of the Project. The
Project will provide the consulting services for capacity strengthening of the regulatory body,
including a training program for its staff.
